# Timeline of Inverkeithing

The following is a timeline of the history of Inverkeithing in Fife, Scotland.
1st century
* 79 AD - 87 AD - During the Roman Conquest of Britain, it is likely Governor Agricola established an encampment in the Inverkeithing area during his war against the Caledonians.
12th century
* 1114 - Inverkeithing is mentioned in the foundation charter of Scone Abbey granted by Alexander I. This is the earliest surviving documentation of Inverkeithing.
* 1161 - Inverkeithing has been granted Royal Burgh status; it is mentioned as an existing royal burgh under the reign of Malcolm IV.
* 1163 - Pope Alexander III's summons the clergy of Inverkeithing to the British Isles Council of Tours.
* 1196 - A hostel for pilgrims in Inverkeithing is documented as a possession of Dryburgh Abbey.
13th century
* 1244, 24 August - Inverkeithing's medieval church was consecrated to St. Peter by Bishop de Bernham.
* 1282 - According to the Lanercrost Chronicle, a scandal of Inverkeithing parish priest. At Easter, the priest "revived the profane rites of Priapus, collecting young girls from the villages, and compelling them to dance in circles to the honour of Father Bacchus, [...] singing and dancing himself and stirring them to lust by filthy language." When the priest exhibited similar behaviour during Lent, a scandalised citizen stabbed him to death.
* 1286, 19 March - King Alexander III is last seen in Inverkeithing, before dying in a storm on route to Kinghorn.
14th century
* 1304, 2 March - King Edward I of England, known as the Hammer of the Scots, stays in Inverkeithing on his return to Scotland during the First War of Scottish Independence.
* 1354, April - The Parliament of Scotland meets at Inverkeithing.
* 1385 - Inverkeithing Franciscan Friary is mentioned to have been built.
15th century
* 1429 - Inverkeithing Burgh authorities were reimbursed for expenses from landing and passing through the town by Princess Elizabeth, daughter of King James I.
* 1487 - Act of Parliament during the reign of James III specifies that the Convention of Royal Burghs will be held annually in Inverkeithing.
16th century
* 1504, November - following a plague scare at Dunfermline Palace, four African women including Ellen More, with John Mosman, the court apothecary, came to stay in Inverkeithing.
* 1557 - Stone town walls were added around Inverkeithing, the last remains of which can still be found on the south side of Roman Road.
* 1598 - Inverkeithing was granted a charter of confirmation as a Royal Burgh by James VI.
17th century
* 1611 - the parishes of Inverkeithing and Rosyth were united.
* 1621 - six local women are tried for witchcraft at Inverkeithing Tolbooth.
* 1621 to 1652 - at least 51 people are executed for witchcraft in Inverkeithing.
* 1651, 20 July - the Battle of Inverkeithing.
18th century
* 1707, 9 April - Robert Balfour becomes known for a crime of passion in Inverkeithing.
* 1707 - James Spittle, representing Inverkeithing, votes in favour of retification of the Treaty of Union with England (see Acts of Union).
19th century
* 1821 - merchant and politician Sir Robert Preston directed the development of Preston Crescent.
* 1835 - lazaretto at Inverkeithing is decommissioned, after being constructed in the early 19th century.
20th century
* 1930 - Inverkeithing was granted its own Burgh Arms, a coat of arms for Royal Burghs. These were based on the oldest known Burgh seals, which date from 1296 and 1357.
* 1975 - Inverkeithing ceases to be a Royal Burgh and becomes part of Fife Council.
21st century
* 2019 - a 5-year project sees 298 new homes built at Spencerfields, Inverkeithing, expanding the town eastwards.
